thread.title: Improving jobs market helps subprime lender Provident Financial
thread.title_full: Improving jobs market helps subprime lender Provident Financial

author: Marion Dakers
title: Improving jobs market helps subprime lender Provident Financial
text:
Improving jobs market helps subprime lender Provident Financial Provident Financial says more customers are paying their credit card bills The Office for National Statistics said employment rose by 140,000 over the three months to August Photo: PA Comments 
Subprime lender Provident has said the improving UK jobs market has buoyed its credit card business in the three months to the end of September. 
The company has spent several years trimming back its doorstep lending business, which now has about 1m customers, to focus on other types of credit aimed at Britons who would struggle to access loans elsewhere. 
Vanquis, the credit card provider that generates most of Provident’s profits, reported a 12pc rise in customer numbers and a 21pc rise in outstanding loans. 
“Delinquency levels have remained favourable through the third quarter, reflecting the sound quality of the receivables book and an improving employment market,” the company said. 
The firm’s online short-term lender Satsuma increased its customer base to 53,000 and had £14m of outstanding loans by the end of September. The company expects it to break even next year, as the new Financial Conduct Authority registration of all consumer lenders pushes many competitors out of the market. 
Glo, Provident’s new guarantor loan platform, has been given the green light to continue lending after a successful trial period. Meanwhile its recently-acquired car finance outfit Moneybarn added 3,000 customers to take its total to 29,000, who have £209m of loans receivable. 
“Credit quality in these businesses is sound which leaves the group in good shape to deliver further good-quality growth as it enters the important fourth-quarter trading period,” said Peter Crook, chief executive. 
Cenkos analysts raised their full-year forecasts to assume revenues of £1.13bn and adjusted pre-tax profits of £291m for the year. 
“It is a good statement, and confidence appears high going into the fourth quarter – traditionally, Provident’s busiest period ahead of Christmas trading,” said analysts at Citi. 
Shares in the FTSE 250 company opened 3pc higher following the update.
